Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 08:25PM take_two wrote: The only things on my Christmas list are a good pathology report and my drains out.  Well I got one of the two today - the good path report.  They still found 1.5 mm of DCIS in the "evil twin's" tissues even though the lumpectomy a month ago was supposed to have taken everything and had clear margins, but it is still only DCIS and treatment is done with the BMX.  The good twin side only had benign issues.  I did chemo and radiation last time and am glad I don't have to go that route again.    My heart hurts for those of you with the opposite outcome, but you will get through this!!  If it helps in any way, my original cancer diagnosis 10 years ago turned out to be a blessing.  My life is so much better now than it was then.  I changed my career, I've made so many new friends, and make so much more of a difference to people, survivors and non, than I could have with the environmental job that I had.  I could never have imagined it would have had such a positive impact, and I wouldn't trade it for the world.  vis0121 - keep in mind that high grade cells tend to respond to chemo better so if there is that errant cell, chemo should take care of it.  Even though chemo sucks it did help me buy some piece of mind last time (I was 31).  Even so, it took a long time till cancer didn't creep into my thoughts consistently. riley702 - I too had a reaction to Keflex with rash on my neck.  It took about a week for the bumps to start to go away, even though the itching diminshed faster.  Good luck with that.   Julia - I'm not exactly sure what you are seeing.  I have a concavity at the top, but also some weird looking curved rises and indentations from the drains under the skin.  If what you are describing is not from the drains, I work with a lot of survivors and a concavity seems pretty common.  Many women expect to end up with a chest like a flat man's after a mastectomy, but men have more muscle and some fat overlying, which we don't so the area ends up concave. Either way, I'm sure the PS will take care of it.  Are you doing the fat grafting?  I am. Pink - depending on the chemo "cocktail" the side effects may not be that bad.  I had pretty nasty chemo ten years ago, and other than the fact that it sucked at the time and I had way worse side effects from it than anyone else they had given that treatment to, it only lasted 3 months and I had no residual effects.  I was half your age, but even so, for me the trade off and peace of mind was worth it. They should be able to put you in touch with people who have experienced what treatment they are recommending and that firsthand experience may help with your decision.  Best of luck making up your mind, and remember you can always change it - a survivor's prerogative.
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 07:52PM take_two wrote: Julia - I can't address the food/supplement questions, but my surgeon suggested I keep my chest and myself a little extra warm to promote good blood flow.  He suggested always wearing a fleece vest or something to add another layer.  He also stressed no heating pads because you can't feel when you are burning or overheating your skin.  I've been enjoying the heat turned up in the house a little and my fleece lined shirt from LL Bean. It's heavenly.  Congrats on the path report!

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 07:26PM take_two wrote: Sorry I don't have a pic yet, but I just got a great summer dress at Title Nine that looks pretty good breast free.  It's gathered in the center of the chest which makes it work well. It also has a shelf bra if anyone wants to get creative with their shower scrunchy.  www.titlenine.com  Under dresses look for the Impress Dress.  Under bathing suits the Stay Put and Salvation bikini or takini worked pretty well too.  Summer's coming, I hope!

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2010 04:08PM take_two wrote: A friend of mine who's had a BMX commented to me that it's great to have it in December if you have to have one because soon it will be something that happened LAST YEAR and the new year will be a new beginning.  Annie - no one is ever wacko for finding the good in any situation, regardless of what it is.  Happy B-day. zogo - congrats on the drains  My turn soon.  Best wishes to all....

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 12:01AM take_two wrote: vis0121,  Sorry to hear about your path report.  I am anxiously awaiting mine on Tuesday.  I had very aggressive IDC 10 years ago and did chemo and radiation after my lumpectomy.  It was doable.  I wore a wig most of the time out in public and hats at home.  Having negative nodes is great news, and since you had the MX you won't end up here again like I did.  Your surgery probably took care of everything and chemo will just be insurance. Keep your chin up and best wishes, Cathy

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 07:54PM take_two wrote: Hi Carla, I'm another you can add to the list.  I'm having a simple (no nodes) BMX on the 16th for a recurrence 10-years following my original diagnosis.  I'm planning to try to get a ski day in the 15th before the surgery puts a damper on my season for a while.  Thanks for creating this thread.  -Cathy
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 12:19AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:25AM by take_two Hi gals, I made it to the other side too.  Everything went great.  I had a simple (no nodes) skin and nipple sparing MX with no reconstruction yet and was done about 2 pm.  I think not having any nodes taken out really makes this easier, because my lumpectomy and SNB 10 years ago seemed more painful.  I have absolutely no problems with nausea, etc after surgeries, so the only bad time was when the nurses tried to tell me I was on a liquid only diet until morning.  I was starving so got grumpy and made a bit of a fuss.  They relented.  I was walking around by 4:30.  When my BS saw me at 5:30 pm he said I was doing so well that I was welcome to go home.  So I stayed for my dinner and some pre-planned visits from gals from the cancer survivor exercise class I teach (thurs eve is the usual class time and the hospital was right across the street from the studio).  After that I packed up went home.  I'm getting a little tired now, so am looking forward to sleeping in my own bed.  I'm only taking advil right now and just feel as if I did too many push up yesterdays (e.g., some soreness but not pain), but may take some oxycodone to make sure to knock me out tonight.    BTW, I only have clear bandages over my incisions so I can see everything.  It's very strange to look down and see empty breast pockets except for the drain tube bulges, but otherwise it's not too bad.  I'm happy to be on the road to recovery, am looking forward to my shower on Saturday, and am hoping for a good pathology report on Tuesday.  Thanks for the kind words all....
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 08:29PM take_two wrote: Hi all, For the benefit of those coming after us, I thought I'd post an update.  It's been just over 48 hours since I woke up in recovery.  I came home a few hours after my simple nipple and skin sparing BMX (BS gave me the option).  I haven't had to take much pain medication.  My BS wants me to take advil for a few days to minimize swelling, and that's all I've needed.  I was fairly tired the day after, but much better today.  My muscles are sore, but improving and I'm doing some stretching exercises as requested.  Thankfully there haven't been any issues with any portion my digestive tract. The drains are the biggest hassle.  They are somewhat uncomfortable and because of where they exit I can only sleep on my back.  My back does not like that after 6 hours or so.  Thankfully, the seepage is decreasing and clearing so I'm really hoping that they'll come out before Christmas.  The best part of this was that my surgeon told my husband I'm not to do chores for 2 years.  I wish!  Best wishes to you ladies with surgeries this coming week.  -Cathy
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2010 10:58AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:26AM by take_two Megan, My surgeon said I could drive as soon as I felt like  it once I reached 4-5 days post-op IF I felt completely safe.  In other words, I could handle emergency steering and I wasn't on narcotics. I'm four and a half days out and feel like I could drive, but I don't have to be anywhere so plan to sit tight for a day or two yet.  Hope that helps. Good clothing suggestions - I'll be heading out soon and I still have a couple of drain days.  These things are a pain - literally and otherwise!!   -Cathy
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 11:37AM take_two wrote: vis0121 - My diagnosis 10 years ago was a 1 cm lump, mostly IDC with some DCIS mixed in.  High grade (grade 3) with "worrisome neuclear atypia", very strongly Her2/neu+ , strongly ER positive, weakly PR positive.  I had a lumpectomy and SNB.  Nodes were clear.  Treatment was 4 cycles of Adriamycin/Cytoxan/5-FU hell.  I didn't have to take taxol since I was node clear, and it was before the days of Herceptin.  Then I did about 7 weeks of radiation including a boost, then 5 years of tamoxifen since I was pre-menopausal. I had just come home from my 10-year survivor anniversary trip of backpacking in the Alps this summer to find another lump at my lumpectomy site and start the game again.  Both times I found the lump and the mammo couldn't see it due to my dense tissues.  It was 0.6 mm DCIS.  This time my other side wanted to get in the game too and had some atypical lobular hyperplasia.  I ended up having 4 different biopsies (I've officially had every type possible) and a surgical biopsy and lumpectomy before the BMX.  I think they either wanted to make money off me or make me happy to have a mastectomy.  They accomplished both, but I did have my MX elsewhere since my original surgeon wouldn't do nipple sparing on someone with a recurrence, yet other surgeons felt it was fine in my situation of only DCIS that was 5 cm from the nipple.  Apparently the chance of a recurrence was only a couple of percent, as was the chance of getting cancer at such a young age as I was and you are.  Too bad I'm not so lucky with lottery tickets!  ;-)  Best of luck with everything and feel free to message me if I can help in any way.  BTW, for you others out there dealing with not as optimal a diagnosis as expected, it may help to know that I work with lots of survivors through Team Survivor Northwest and Cancer Lifeline and I have 3 friends who are all 5-15 years out of a Stage 3 diagnosis, one with 8 positive nodes, who are all doing great and perfectly healthy, not to mention all the ones with Stage 1 and 2 diagnoses.  There is life after all this, sometimes an even better one.  Best wishes to all on either side of your MX,   -Cathy
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2010 10:58AM take_two wrote: Hi fire-dancer,  Just wanted to let you know that you aren't in this boat alone.  I had my drains removed on the 22nd which were also still outputting 25-30 ml/day and now have fluid build up on both sides.  It's especially annoying on my right side where it seems to be more under the armpit, but there is increased tightness and burning on both sides.  I also have an appt on Wed with my BS.  From a comfort standpoint I'm hoping he'll aspirate both sides, but I also realize that can increase your risk for infection and it may be safest to wait since this is technically tolerable.  I look forward to hearing his recommendations so I can stop dwelling on it.  Good luck with your appt.
Posts.Title: drains out & now fluid is building up - what to do? fire-dancer fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 01:25AM take_two wrote: I did get my fluid aspirated on Wednesday.  I agree with the comment about it's good thing to be numb - that was one big needle.  My doctor thought I was healing wonderfully and didn't think it was a lot of build up being 50 ml or less on each side, but I don't think there was room for any more fluid based on the way I'm healing.  The bummer is that at this rate it will be all back in place within about 48 hours following the aspiration.  Grrr!  At least I've been more comfortable for these 2 days than I would have been.  The worst part is that I still have to maintain my low activity.  I'm two weeks out from surgery and so far, I'm finding sitting still the hardest part of my recovery - my bike and running shoes miss me, there is fresh snow to be skied in the mountains, and my energy level was back to normal after just a few days.  (Can you tell I don't have kids? ;-)  )  Now if I can only get back the remaining 25% of my range of motion and have this fluid build up stop, I'd be home free.  Happy New Year to all and soon all this will something that happened "last year."  I can't wait.
Posts.Title: drains out & now fluid is building up - what to do? fire-dancer fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 09:49AM take_two wrote: I had a great bike session on Tuesday and a great afternoon skiing yesterday.  Now I'm ready to jump and land with the rest of you.  I'm a little anxious but mostly looking forward to getting this behind me and recovering so I can get back to the activities I love.  Thanks the good wishes.  Thinking of you all, especially those of you facing new news in your pathology reports or complications from your surgery.  I'll be back soon....
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 02:41PM take_two wrote: Welcome new December gals, hello again to the rest. I just had my (almost) 3-week BMX check up and I'm so excited that I got the go ahead to start resuming ALL my normal activities.  Anything I want, including skiing and swimming, as long as it doesn't hurt or cause more fluid build up.  Wohoo!   I'm still working on the last 20% or so of my shoulder range of motion and still have a bit of an issue with fluid, but my surgeon was only able to aspirate 18 ml this week on my worst side, compared to 50 ml last week.  I am back at work as of this week and since my energy level has felt normal for a while now it's great to finally be out of the house and to see all my clients, etc.  They have been such wonderful supporters. I'm another young'ish (42), dense-breasted gal who had imaging and diagnosing issues despite having palpable lumps.  I'm so thankful I found it before it became invasive this time as I did chemo and rads 10 years ago before my recurrence this year.  Once was enough.  I must say that it feels rather freeing to not have my time-bombs anymore. For you gals going through all this for the first time, I want to say that there can be a normal life after all this.  In my case it was even better than the before-BC normal because it provided the impetus to follow some paths I would have been scared to otherwise.  You can do this and be stronger for it.  Best wishes all.
Posts.Title: December 2010 Mastectomy zogo fire-dancer
